 Well, elections are often close nationally; 4 since WWII were virtual ties (1948, 1960, 1976 and 2000). In such an election, your voting power is the probability that, without your vote, it is a tie (if even # of votes) or within 1 vote (if odd). To calculate this properly, you need to model the probability of a voter showing up, of voting for each candidate, and the correlation between the two. That is hard, but a simplified model might just assume that the number of voters is fixed and each flips a coin. Say there are exactly 100 million voters. If you know what a binomial distribution is and how to approximate is by a normal distribution, you can type "=NORMSDIST(1/SQRT(25000000))-0.5" in Excel, and you'll get 0.0000797... as the result. That is approx. 1 divided by 12,500. This is not what one would normally call "virtually zero". (It is less than the probability of getting four-of-a-kind, but more than that of getting a straight flush, in a poker hand w/o exchanges.)
 
 Now an analogous model for Utah or DC would have each voter toss a biased coin with 80% or so chance for one party. Let there be 500,000 voters; then your Excel formula becomes "=NORMSDIST(150000/SQRT(80000))-NORMSDIST(150001/SQRT(80000))" and the result is way beyond Excel's precision, so it will give you a zero.  You see, the largest population centers (California, New York, NJ) voted for Gore. But the majority of states voted for Bush. Neither had 50%+1 of the popular vote. A minority would have elected the president and it Would have been the result of the largest population centers.
 
 That would have misrepresented the majority of states. The electoral college prevents the smaller states from being picked on by the larger states. Bush had a majority of the electoral votes. There were no renegade electors. He had 50%+1 at least of the electors. The states were appropriately represented.

My biggest problem with the Electoral College is that it functions on a "winner take all" basis. To put it simply, if a presidential candidate wins 51% of the vote in a state, he gets 100% of the electoral vote from that state. This only furthers the "wasted vote" system, because the 49% of the voters in the state who voted for other candidates do not get their vote represented. Talk about majoritarian dictatorship!
 
 The question of abolishing the electoral college depends on what we replace it with. A popular-vote plurality winner system is the most obvious solution, but there has been another proposal - instant runoff voting.

I'm for a popular vote with instant runoff voting. Why?
 
 - The electoral college system essentially throws away the minority votes in a given state due to the winner take all scheme. A Democrat friend of mine in Texas says that her vote hasn't counted in a presidential election in years. Demoralizing voters seems counter-productive.
 
 - The electoral numbers can elect a president who doesn't win the popular vote. Talk about a great way to divide the country. My guy won! No, my  guy won!
 
 - The arguments about the electoral college giving all the small states a big voice is a load of rubbish. What it does is focus everyone's attention on a small handful of swing states. How many times did you hear political analysts talk about Rhode Island vs. Florida/Ohio?
 
 - Electors in many states can legally vote for whoever they want, regardless of who the majority of people in that state voted for. I don't want to entrust some nameless elector (can you name yours?) with this kind of power. This mechanism was put into the system to protect the people from themselves, which seems overly cynical for the society we have now.
 
 - Instant runoff voting is the only way we're ever going to break out of the two-party system (fast becoming a one-party system)
 
 - Florida, Florida, Florida. Marcia, Marcia, Marcia. Aren't you the least bit tired of having presidential elections decided by a single swing state? Why should Florida be the center of the American political universe?
